item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickies to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: After reading your blog post I browsed your website a bit and noticed you aren’t ranking nearly as well in Google as you could be. I possess a handful of blogs myself and I think you should take a look here: http://dominateseowithwordpress.com You’ll find it’s a very nice tool that can bring you a lot more visitors. Keep up the quality posts

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The web has given documentarians a powerful mechanism to distribute their films, but we have only scratched the surface of how it can change storytelling.  The Living Docs Project sees the web as a canvas on which new types of documentary can be created. The web offers a shared commons of images and sounds, conversations, and data about our politics, our histories, ourselves. It transforms audiences into active participants. It opens the door to documentaries that are living, changing, and constantly evolving works. "Living Docs" are the descendants of moving images, but start to look at lot like software in their structure and approach.  Like software, these new documentaries put the user at the center of the experience - allowing them to explore environments, contribute media and in some cases be the subject of the work.  Yet like the best documentaries, they are grounded in real human stories and experiences. We believe that the open ethos of the web —shared collaboration, constant learning, and iterative development—lights the way for a fundamentally new way of producing documentary.  These new ways of working require new skills, new teams, and new aesthetics. The Living Docs project seeks to address these needs by:
  • Hosting Hack Days that pair web developers and documentarians to rapidly prototype web documentaries.  We believe that making things is a joy, and a necessary process in order to develop a common vocabulary between those who create the web and those who create documentaries.
  • Highlighting projects that we love and support.  It takes a village to build a documentary, and we'll point to projects that we've funded, supported, that use our technology, or that we simply want more people to experience.
  •  Documenting best practices and sharing lessons learned.  We want documentarians sharing their experiences, their challenges and victories, and also their code. Via a blog that partners contibute to regularly, we'll follow these projects and the emerging field and create original content that celebrates the genre
  • Sharing code.  The explosive growth of the web owes itself to the ability of others to "view source".  By seeing how the web is put together, we not only learn how to do create original new work, but are given a shortcut to creating new work by building on our peers.  We will help documentarians do this, and to sort through the narrative and business implications that it brings.
  •  Funding for the creation of web documentaries.  The doc world is changing as the role of broadcasters shift and audiences attention is fractured.  New methods of supporting the art of documentary must exist on the web if this fledgling genre is to thrive.  We'll offer a path to production financing that is at the same time grounded in sharing resources, so that all documentarians can share in our efforts.
PARTNERS Mozilla  Mozilla believes that users of the web should also be makers of the web. We support documentarians via the Mozilla Popcorn project, a set of technologies for linking media to the web.  We also run events, host gatherings, and create curricula that teaches "web making" skills and literacies. Tribeca believes X and does Y American U believes Y and does Zed ITVS Feels A, Does B, Suports C. BAVC Feels A, Does B, Suports C.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start blogging!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi, this is a comment.
To delete a comment, just log in and view the post's comments. There you will have the option to edit or delete them.
